name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
refused to even acknowledge that data had been compromised. They hid behind statements like "biometric data is still safe", even though other data had been compromised. This kind of irresponsible behaviour cannot be allowed when privacy is a fundamental right. 

We need to know.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
addressed yet. There can be norms for timelines,but to not make it mandatory to inform users is to rob them of their right to know, & protect themselves.

We saw this with UIDAI. Aadhaar data of millions of people was published online by govt depatments, but Indian govt

7/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
regarding whether users should be informed. This approach is also problematic.

The only reason for not informing users about their data breach is to protect the reputation of someone, either a company or a government department. Worst case scenario:the vulnerability has not 
6/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
India does not have a data protection law, but if the draft bill were the law how would that work?

It would still not be a users right to know. Under the draft bill, when there is a breach, the company has to inform the data protection authority, who has the final say 
5/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Facebook might not know of all the users whose data has been breached here but some users have checked their data via some of these sites, like the one by @troyhunt. Why can't facebook inform at least those people that these sites know about? Best efforts basis?
4/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Out whether our data has been leaked (mine hasn't). Millions of people do not. They deserve to know.

It is Facebook's responsibility to inform users. Even if passwords haven't been scraped. This data can be used with other data. Users need to be warned of risks 
3/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Frankly it's ridiculous that Facebook can even choose not to notify users that their data can be breached. Should be illegal. It shouldn't be their choice. It's not their data.

You & I might read the news & know abt the breach. We might know how to find sites that help us
2/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
It's an absolute shame that Facebook is not notifying users that their data has been breached. This impacts 500 million users worldwide, and from what I've read and an estimated 6.1 million in India. 

1/n
retweet_text: None

Seed and A financing: disrupted.

Now that you can raise $5M/year online, the new strategy for any founder may be to (a) set up an equity crowdfunding link, (b) get a few brand name angels, and (c) tweet it out and have them RT.

Easier for everyone. And way faster. https://t.co/A169054O42

Ravi Shankar Prasad can't use due diligence guidelines for enforcing traceability of originator. That's not a due diligence requirement.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Javadekar has done no public consultation for regulating streaming services. A self regulatory code already exsits for streaming services. 

Govt doesn't have the legal basis for streaming services regulation. They can't do online content regulation under IT act or cable& tv act.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
I won't be surprised if the "link tax" is a part of the DNPA's agenda. We've already got FDI restrictions on online media, and registration norms, since they were formed.

17/ https://t.co/k6OwYwbIhU
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
9. Indian news publishers want this too: In 2019, at an event in Delhi, an Indian news publisher walked up to me and said we need to have this in India: to get Google and Facebook to pay for news. He said that they had helped with the EU's link tax. 

16/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
8. Fake news will win: Users cant get access to authentic news on platforms and search if they don't allow it. No fact checking in spaces where fake news spreads. Removing authentic news creates room for fake news and propaganda websites. Democracy suffers.

15/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Of the platforms. If platforms stop users from sharing, our readership gets affected. If search stops indexing, our reader acquisition gets reduced. Our credibility gets affected if users can't point towards how our good our work is.

14/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
They were greedy. They fed the big tech beast. They didn't put in enough effort into their own distribution. Got easy audiences.

7. Small publications will suffer if governments take the same approach as Australia. We've gotten more reach and beneficial distribution because
13/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
If publishers have failed to adapt, I don't see why the govt should step in to save them against those who did. Or to tax those who served audiences better. Publishers have paid for distribution offline. They ceded it almost completely to search and social media online.
12/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
And it was well thought out. This from 2012 
https://t.co/aztAgok1lL

They build reach, allowed sharing, monitored data and growth hacked, built products and built an audience engagement program. 

Other publishers did not. 
11/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
... an absolutely spectacular job. They've got over 200 million monthly uniques on their sites and apps, & are on most media buyers media plan. They compete for ad spends w Google and Facebook in India. It should be a global case study on how to adapt media to digital.

10/

10/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
They created this power asymmetry because it helped them. They didn't work on building their own distribution. They ceded ground to big tech. 

7. In contrast, look at the Times of India group in India. Under @satyan , Times Internet has done...
9/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
6. Publishers chose this trap: if publishers are over dependent on social media, it's because they chose this. The guardian signed up for instant articles (then left). Most publishers have chosen to be indexed & searchable. They did this because it brought them more audience.

8/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Charging platforms for our sharing, inhibits sharing. Platforms can block. Charging search for indexing hurts discovery. It's like charging an encyclopaedia for aggregating facts. It hurts public interest. Governments don't like big tech, but users are being harmed more here.

7/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Facebook doesn't index news like Google does anyway. Users like you and me share news on it. 

5. Breaks the internet: the internet works for us because we are able to link to things and share links with each other. We find things because search engines index links. 
6/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
4. There's no compulsion: Google doesn't need to index news. Users want news and Google prioritises news on search results anyway, but publishers can prevent Google from indexing using their robots.txt exclusions. No one is forcing publications from being indexed.

5/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
and is now offering it “significant payments” for featuring it's publications in its News Showcase. This is a bad precedent in my opinion. Microsoft waded into this debate and supported what Australia was doing.

Why is this bad?
4/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Price for Google to surface news. For users to share on FB.

2. Power imbalance: Australian competition commission believes there's a power imbalance between News publishers and social media platforms. This is true. 

3. Google has done a deal with Rupert Murdoch's News corp

3/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. What's going on?
A proposed News Media Bargaining Code released by the Australian competition watchdog forces Google and Facebook to enter into arbitration with news publishers to decide a price for News on their platforms. 
https://t.co/v2fUtg2Kuu

2/
retweet_text: None

text:
I was on @alexandermats show on ET Now yesterday, to discuss Facebook and Google vs Australia when it comes to News content, and how they've taken different approaches. 

The key question: can this happen in India?

A thread 👇

1/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: Nischal says that in the EU there is a new rule that allows tax authorities in one jurisdiction to pull KYC data from an…
retweet_text: Nischal says that in the EU there is a new rule that allows tax authorities in one jurisdiction to pull KYC data from another. The concern for the government and regulators is whether money is being withdrawn for legitimate purposes or to legitimate accounts, he said

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @advait_palepu: On KYC and AML concerns

“I would say our Know-Your-Customer practices is on par with the banking industry or any other…
retweet_text:
On KYC and AML concerns

“I would say our Know-Your-Customer practices is on par with the banking industry or any other financial services entity in India. I think the point of contention comes from what happens after you have bought the cryptocurrency."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: "“When I hear that CBDCs are going to be the Bitcoin killer, it is saying Facebook can be Google Google search. But thos…
retweet_text: "“When I hear that CBDCs are going to be the Bitcoin killer, it is saying Facebook can be Google Google search. But those are two different products with different use cases."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: "I would personally think of an institutional approach first, because you can make that efficient. If our banks can talk…
retweet_text: "I would personally think of an institutional approach first, because you can make that efficient. If our banks can talk to each other quickly, instantly, I think that’s going to make the banking system in India far more efficient."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @advait_palepu: On Central Bank-backed Digital Currencies 

Nischal says that a wholesale CBDC has more use-value than a retail CBDC. "I…
retweet_text:
On Central Bank-backed Digital Currencies 

Nischal says that a wholesale CBDC has more use-value than a retail CBDC. "I think at the national level, I’m a big fan of UPI and what the RBI has done. I think it’s beautiful. No other country has done it. So kudos to us."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: "Bad actors can be kept in check while we eat a larger part of the pie that exists. If the crypto-market today is worth…
retweet_text: "Bad actors can be kept in check while we eat a larger part of the pie that exists. If the crypto-market today is worth $1 trillion, India could easily eat 10-20% of that, which would be great for our economy."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: "Due to the nature of crypto-currencies, none of the existing regulators are in a position to regulate. So I’m guessing…
retweet_text: "Due to the nature of crypto-currencies, none of the existing regulators are in a position to regulate. So I’m guessing that the government will probably give some powers to one of the regulators."

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @advait_palepu: "The government wants to minimise negative impact, and that’s fine. But you cannot just think about how to minimise the…
retweet_text: "The government wants to minimise negative impact, and that’s fine. But you cannot just think about how to minimise the negative impact, we also have to see how to maximize the positive impact"

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:

On the proposal to ban crypto trading and investments

text: RT @pranesh: Secret censorship orders are anathema to rule of law in a democracy, even if those censorship orders are purportedly related t…
retweet_text: Secret censorship orders are anathema to rule of law in a democracy, even if those censorship orders are purportedly related to "public order". Prima facie, the govt hasn't issued notice to those whose writings it seeks to censor. Doing so is required by the law. 3/n

name: Nikhil Pahwa

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Twitter is also taking the jurisdictional defence: that it is a US entity and not governed by Indian laws. It's a foolhardy approach, and no sovereign nation can -- and should not -- tolerate such an approach. Twitter would do better to not take such an approach.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Someone I spoke with yesterday believed that under Section 69A, if Twitter doesn't comply, they lose safe harbor. Safe Harbor (which protects platforms) is under Section 79A. It is my (non-lawyerly) understanding that Section 69A doesn't have this protection.

Students have to submit exam forms, but without the web and schools shut, they couldn't figure out when. Anxiety.

name: Nikhil Pahwa

3. What exactly is life like that? Last year, we (@medianama) asked Kashmir journalist @AakashHassan to write for us on what life is like under an Internet Shutdown in Kashmir. Excerpts:

retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
According to https://t.co/4M3jhAH98b by @SFLCin , since 2012, there have been 251 Internet Shutdowns in Jammu & Kashmir. 

- 221 from 2017-2020. 189 from 2018-2020. 
- That's an average fof 63 Internet Shutdowns a year between 2018-2020. 

Imagine life like that.

6/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. Kashmir is no stranger to Internet Shutdowns. As per @SFLCin tracker, the 3 longest shutdowns in India have been in Jammu & Kashmir (including Kargil). Each has been over 100 days. I would count firewalling and 2G only Internet as a shutdown, tbh.

5/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
- In August 2020, Udhampur and Ganderbal got 4G Internet on a trial basis. Pre-paid subscribers needed police verification, and there was MAC binding. 
https://t.co/b6ACuM4zLL

4/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
- A firewall was put in Jan 2020, allowing access to 301 websites eventually. 
https://t.co/bSs0L4L4xw
- Access to social media sites was enabled in March 2020. 

3/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. History: 
- 4G had been cut in Kashmir in August 4, 2019. 
- End of Jan 2020, fixed line services had been allowed, and 2G was enabled (which, given how heavy Internet sites are now, is excruciatingly slow)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Heartening news yesterday: 4G services have finally been restored in Kashmir. It has been a year and half of no/almost-no Internet. 

Can you even imagine what that's like in today's day and age? 

A few points and thoughts in this thread:

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
This was pre-facebook acquisition. Competition was fierce. WhatsApp won that battle. 

As Signal scales, for it to make it viable for people to switch, it has to get this right. With the privacy settings it has. 

It has Bryan Acton, who knows this. 

All the best to Signal.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Lots of them incorporated new, cool features.

Some did stickers. Some incorporated news feeds. Some had an Indian language interface. Voice calls. Audio messages.

WhatsApp focused on one thing, and one thing only: making sure messages reach you on time, for everyone. At scale
+
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Signal has been down off and on since last night.

It is learning now what messaging at India scale feels like. Let me remind you about 2008-14: there was whatsapp, viber, jaxtr, Nimbuzz, plustxt, rocketalk, hike, kik, Im+, eBuddy, line, and some more.
+

Since I'm receiving lots of Q's on my views on the Trump Ban and Parler ban by platforms (Twitter, Facebook etc), I thought write about it. Here's how I think about this issue:

This is about power: As long as Trump hadn't lost the election, he wielded significantly more power
1/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
6. Will platforms be more accountable against hate speech in the future? Of course they wont. Least of all from powerful people. Not unless they're regulated and there's an expectation of reasonable action and accountability, as per laws.
16.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
5. Should they have banned Trump? Yes, I think so. Platforms should ban all incitement to violence, & all organising of violence, all threats. Do they do it for everyone? Of course they don't. You have to see comments that targeting women & women journalists on Twitter.  
15/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ Remember the controversy in India against Ankhi Das for favoring a BJP politician inciting violence? Remember Facebook not disabling the incitement against Rohingyas? Or Twitter allowing ISIS handles? When it gets called out, they act.
14/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ a public function, they are still private platforms. They can impose their own terms. They can be the arbiters of truth on their property. They only need to seem reasonable to you & me to ensure that we remain. And they can be brutally cold & calculating about power. 
13/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
4.3 Can they ban Trump and get away with it? Of course they can. Can platforms be held liable for banning someone? Nope. Platforms have responsibility (to ensure a safe space) but no liability or accountability to do so. Even though these are private platforms performing 

12/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ If there is no restriction, then incidents like this happen. If there is a restriction, it can lead to arbitrary (and at times unintentional) censorship. The thinking is that more speech is good, and we shouldn't rule based on exceptions. 

11/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ because you cannot rule by exception: exceptional situations like what happened with the US Capitol and incitement to violence cannot lead to overbearing restrictions that end up silencing legitimate speech. Speech is complicated. 
10/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ protecting speech itself. Platforms use this trade-off in regulation to their advantage.

4.2 Speech is complicated: Policymakers choose to let platforms get away with negligence when it comes to enabling harmful conduct (drip-feeding of hate, live streaming shootings) 
9/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ Twitter is a global public sphere. Facebook is connecting people. etc. Can they ban you or me? Sure they can. It's private property. At the same time, you need free speech to be protected, & protecting the platforms that enable free speech is just as important as 
8/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
4. Can platforms ban him?Are platforms wrong in banning him?It's complicated. I'll explain:
4.1 Public function, private spaces: Platforms are private spaces performing a public function, & in order to ensure their own protection, position themselves as global public spaces. 
7/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ abuse, it's a small problem. Some times countries behave this way too: if 0.01% of people using Aadhaar in India cant get rations because fingerprint auth fails, it's a minor issue, even if it can lead to a few people dying (it has). 

6/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ problems/harm for a few people as long as it's small in percentage terms. It allows them to scale usage at very little cost, and by the time the problems are very large, they put in processes to deal with them. If 0.1% of people out of 100 million using Twitter face vicious 
5/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ There may still be a push for modifying safe harbor, but there's now scope for a reasonable debate about the changes, as opposed to when Trump was using that as a threat. 

3. Platforms do too little too late: If history is anything to go by, platforms are okay with extreme 
4/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ Trump is out in the cold now, and his speech on these platforms is at the platforms mercy, like for you and me.

2. This is (a little bit) also about revenge: Trump has attacked platforms, and threatened to repeal their primary protection (safe harbor/230 of the CDC). 

3/
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ than the platforms. They feel more confident about these bans now that he has lost, because there can't be retaliation from him. There also won't be retaliation from other politicians in power: there is significant bipartisan condemnation against him. 
2/
retweet_text: None

TikTok remains that threat for instagram, with massive network effects.

Network effects are portable.

It's not impossible.

Network effects can also work for platforms being migrated to. 

Might not happen here but doesn't mean it can't. Orkut, myspace are clear examples.

Thank you everyone for reading our stories and supporting our journalism

text:
Whataboutery. My response:
1. Govts have more accountability to citizens than social networks. 
2. Am here by choice. Govt forced Aarogya Setu on ppl.
3. It's not either-or. Both need accountability. I have also raised Q's about social networks.Look it up.
https://t.co/vs4BgMR7Mi

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 19. Aarogya Setu has been brought in & forced upon citizens without a law - even a temporary law like Singapore has - which seems to be in violation of the Right to Privacy judgment. I would urge @SFLCin and also @internetfreedom to challenge Aarogya Setu on these grounds.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
18. Note that @SFLCin and @anivar have filed an important case against Aarogya Setu in challenging its mandatory usage. The Karnataka HC has said that without law, govt cannot deny services for not installing Aarogya Setu. 

This is the new Aadhaar.
(23/n)
https://t.co/E8bwWLO6ee

name: Nikhil Pahwa

9. Reminder: This policy change has been finalised without public consultation. Representations they've received are not in the public domain. 
10. Digital Media co's need to brace for another policy: Registration of Periodicals and Publications Bill, 2019 (10/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 8. Additional restrictions, probably targeting The Wire: CEO has to be an Indian citizen. Foreign citizens employed need govt security clearance, and if not cleared, will have to resign. (9/n) https://t.co/6SBEKMeLBz
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 7. Digital News co's will get 1 year to restructure to comply within these guidelines. Digital news companies restructure to set up co's in Singapore, & raise funds in SG from here on. This means there will be less FDI in Digital Media in India. (8/n) https://t.co/etUjViyFlg
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 6. There's an increase in govt control over digital news media by controlling funding. Now you'll need government permission to raise funds. Instead of liberalising news media, easing restrictions on print, they've taken digital to the level of control they have on print.(7/n) https://t.co/gJNyHGLx1A
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 5. What about Facebook and YouTube, where news content is posted by users? They, by definition, will be news aggregators. Note how it specifically mentions "user submitted links" in the clarification. They do have India entities. (6/n) https://t.co/wFgrlsu0s5
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 4. The impact on news aggregators is particularly tricky. Will DailyHunt be impacted? Probably. Inshorts might be impacted too. What about Google News? They aren't a registered entity in India, even as an aggregator. (5/n) https://t.co/FwKy8kDeiJ
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 3. This might impact local bureaus of international publications too. Many contribute directly to websites,and not to television or radio. Not clear exactly what the impact will be, but this part of the clarification is worrying for them: (4/n) https://t.co/aHVRiMKXPU
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 2. This move strengthens the traditional media lobby against digital companies. Traditional media co's had formed a digital lobby group in 2018. This is probably their doing: https://t.co/pdPY9XUEIy (3/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. Govt is positioning this as a benefit. That's incorrect. FDI has been reduced from 100% to 26%. How do we know it was 100%? NewsCorp had bought VCCircle in 2015: https://t.co/gH9CLk2glU They've now sold it at a loss to Mint, after the FDI policy was announced.
(2/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
The Indian government has today "clarified" it's position on Foreign Investment in Digital News Media in India. 

It is restricting FDI to 26%, in line with print, and not just in media companies, but in news aggregators too. 

https://t.co/JE2bpvveA7

Thread 👇 (1/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 9. Is this why India banned Chinese apps: data gathering? I think that's just a ruse they're using. In my opinion, they've banned because of the armed forces standoff, as a political response. Risk of cyber attacks is real. Data collection is not a believable reason for ban. 9/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 8. What can we do? One thing the PDP bill must have, is to enable us to know who is collecting what info about is, and for us to be able to delete that info. If companies like Zenhua don't comply, then we need to mandate that platforms block their access. Not sure what else.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
6. How can this be used? To run targeted disinformation campaigns. In some cases, to run honeypot traps. Can be used for further operations and blackmail. Spy thriller stuff.
7. How will the hawks play this?
They'll demand data localisation, when it really doesn't help here. 
6/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
5. Is it worrying?
Of course it is. Digital enables profiling and targeting at a population scale. Profiling can be harmful and misused by intelligence agencies. (Even by us on our own citizens. Look up NATGRID, btw).

5/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
4. Is this something new? Is it surprising?
Tell me a country that doesn't have a dossier on significant actors in a significant country. India probably has this on the Chinese as well. Probably not of this scale, but every country has it. 
4/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
3. Is identifying/documenting relationships between people using publicly available data illegal? 
It isn't. Journalists do this for stories. LinkedIn does it, quite publicly. Social media = behavioral and relational info
3/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. Is collecting public data off social media illegal? 
It isn't. Much of ad industry is exactly that. Collect data, classify people, target them. But it is surveillance. SC said  about Indian govts social media tender: blanket montioring of social media is mass surveillance.
2/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Q's you have to ask about the IE story on Zenhua and Chinese profiling of significant  Indian folks is: 
1. is profiling illegal? 
It isn't. Not even as per the personal data protection bill. Twitter does it. Facebook does it. LinkedIn does it. Political parties do it.
1/n
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: Bookselling and books are older than DRM (hell, they're older than copyright!). Publishers, booksellers and readers have a (l…

Bookselling and books are older than DRM (hell, they're older than copyright!). Publishers, booksellers and readers have a (literally) ancient compact. The idea that tech monopolists get to wave a lawyer's pen and declare it null and void is, frankly, bullshit.

14/

Both companies offered refunds, but come on.

text:

But it's not just publishers and writers who suffer here - readers get a raw deal from DRM, too. 

Recall that in 2009, Amazon remotely deleted purchased copies of 1984 from readers' Kindles, due to a complaint from the Orwell estate (you can't make this up!)

10/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:

retweet_text:
It's no wonder that farmers are one of the worst-off groups in the US for "deaths of despair" (suicide and overdose). 

Amazon's use of DRM is a key component in its campaign to chickenize publishing, of course.

9/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: Farmers who complain - especially to regulators and lawmakers - are shut out of the market...permanently. One farmer went int…
retweet_text:
Farmers who complain - especially to regulators and lawmakers - are shut out of the market...permanently. One farmer went into the coop-maintenance business and the meat packers told suppliers that if they hired him, they'd be blackballed, too.

8/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: When this is done, the farmer sells their birds to the monopolist, who unilaterally names a price: the monopolists use their…
retweet_text:
When this is done, the farmer sells their birds to the monopolist, who unilaterally names a price: the monopolists use their extensive data-gathering to titrate the money-drip so farmers have just enough to continue for another year, but not enough to get ahead.

7/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: Some farmers are unwitting subjects in experiments - Purdue might decide to test the effect of a different feeding regime and…
retweet_text:
Some farmers are unwitting subjects in experiments - Purdue might decide to test the effect of a different feeding regime and order a farmer to apply it.

6/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: Big Chicken uses this advantage to squeeze suppliers: chicken farmers are told what kind of coop to build, which chicks to bu…
retweet_text:
Big Chicken uses this advantage to squeeze suppliers: chicken farmers are told what kind of coop to build, which chicks to buy, what feed to use, which medicines to dose, even when the lights go on and off.

5/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: The phrase comes from the US poultry industry, where three monopolistic companies have divided up the country so that (nomina…
retweet_text:
The phrase comes from the US poultry industry, where three monopolistic companies have divided up the country so that (nominally independent) chicken farmers have only one processor who'll buy their birds.

4/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @doctorow: But it DOES lock their works to Amazon's platform...forever. 

Labor economists talk about "chickenization" in markets where…
retweet_text:
But it DOES lock their works to Amazon's platform...forever. 

Labor economists talk about "chickenization" in markets where there is a "monopsony" - that is, where a single seller controls access to the market.

3/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @doctorow: DRM isn't hard to break (just google "break audible drm" if you don't believe me!) but it IS a felony to traffick in tools th…
retweet_text:
DRM isn't hard to break (just google "break audible drm" if you don't believe me!) but it IS a felony to traffick in tools that break DRM. That means that the DRM that Amazon forces on creators and publishers in the name of "protecting" them does nothing of the sort.

2/

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Orbi has a vpn option, but that too requires browser -> adv settings. Can't configure via app. Sure you might not want n00b users (I'm not much better than one) messing with adv settings, but why not just put in a warning+ allow ppl to make changes? The ASUS app is so much better
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Why does Netgear to have mimo and beamforming off by default, if these are key features? Why enable these only through advanced settings, and enable access to advanced settings only via browser? What's the point of the app? I switched these on, & now my devices are on 5ghz. 🤷🏽‍♂️
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
So, I finally logged into the router via the browser, and noticed that two key features hadn't been enabled by default: MIMO and something called beamforming. These were hidden away in advanced settings. 

I enabled them, and all these problems got resolved. (So far. 🤞)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: So I looked up forums and found all sorts of complicated solutions to these problems. Netgear forums dating back to 2017 had some of these complaints. Many of the suggestions required browser login, and changes in advanced settings. Wouldn't work with the app.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. Connectivity would work, but the wifi name (SSID) would have a suffix "no internet"
3. When I checked the app, most devices were connected to 2.4ghz. which is pointless for a triband router w two 5ghz channels.
4. Amazon prime video just wouldnt work. I kept getting CDN error.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Netgear seems to yet another hardware co that can't think through software and UX. I set it up using the mobile app, which was easy enough, but problems appeared:
1. At times, randomly, links I'd click on would be blocked. I kept getting 404 errors.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: So I bought a Netgear Orbi router pair - expensive, I know - and it has been giving me trouble since. Old house, thick brick walls, quite a distance from the router: orbi addresses a core problem I have with wiring & range of internet connectivity. I've had several issues.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa

To explain the context: Browsers have an API to let websites detect if your system prefers Dark Mode so websites can change themes accordingly. 

Firefox blocks access to this API if you enable privacy mode coz sites use this 1 bit of information to fingerprint your system.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
I'm deposing before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on IT today, and if you have any solutions for me to share with the committee, please do. 

Tricky part is ensuring our freedoms while regulating bad/biased behavior from/on dominant platforms. (27/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Transparency is our most powerful tool for accountability, but isnt easy. Platforms with transparency reports have to balance political pressure vs transparency. 

Political parties themselves shun transparency. Electoral bonds, anyone?  (26/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: This applies to many large platforms. We have to find better way than removing safe habour. Solutions might about regulating some of these aspects of power through law for any platform. But remember that govts and political parties adapt and will try and fool/bypass norms. (25/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
So what is FB's source of power?
1. Dominance
2. Large user base&reach
3. Ability to control reach
4. Ability to take down accounts,content
5. Intermediary Liability protections/Safe Harbour
6. How algos/humans regulate content
7. Control over ads
8. Lack of transparency 
(24/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: What is clear from recent stories, is that while during Cambridge Analytica, creation of campaigns was a political tool, now takedowns and demands for takedowns are a political weapon. Addressing one party vs another is not a solution. Addressing FB's power is. (23/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: In case of coordinated inauthentic behavior, foreign govts and local political parties create fake accounts and pages, and post content to mislead people in a coordinated manner. Last nights report: from Pak, 453 FB accounts, 103 pages, 78 groups targeting Pak and India (22/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: FB has its own rules. It is making them up as it goes along, as new situations emerge. With each new rule, new problems with implementation emerge. We've seen that in India and US more recently. Political parties will try and bypass these rules. Whack-a-mole will ensue. (21/n)
retweet_text: None

Every party will allege bias against itself. Other networks, apps (ex: NAMO app) can also have bias. (20/n)

8. And it is FB's burden to disprove these signals not ours.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @iam_anandv: 5. So the only right way to think in data-asymmetry environments, is to, ask for more data - meaning ask for a formal inves…

6. But what if you never get it and you would never get it?

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @iam_anandv: 3. Wait and ask for more data. But w/ FB, you can never know, what we don't know. Meaning, there is data asymmetry. So you…
retweet_text:
3. Wait and ask for more data. But w/ FB, you can never know, what we don't know. Meaning, there is data asymmetry. So you can't statistically confirm or deny that there is inherent bias. 

4. Why should it matter? because being clinical works long term.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
because changes in IL could hurt small platforms. We need a middle path between Intermediary Liability Protections and their removal. 
7. Law enforcement also has a responsibility: if hate speech stayed up, and there is incitement to violence, law enforcement also (16/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 6. Intermediary Liability protections: protect platforms from liability but also allow them to impose their own community standards, in the interest of their own community. They're responsible, but we can't hold them liable. We need to be careful here, (15/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 5. Oversight board has insufficient power: As per @chinmayiarun, oversight board FB's oversight board cannot look into implementation of local laws, only content takedowns. It doesn't have the power to look into content that stayed up, despite it being hate speech. (14/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
and their lack of effectiveness was evident when it came to the pandemic, when human moderators were asked to stay home, and algos censored legitimate speech. In the past, Algos censored the Napalm girl photo
(13/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 5. Moderation requires human intervention: The scale of moderating content is huge, and so there are both algos and humans involved. While we want hate speech taken down, we also don't want censorship of free speech. Algos are not great judges of content, (12/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: WhatsApp didn't fix things post Muzaffarnagar riots. Only after @rsprasad repeatedly summoned Chris Daniels. FB responds when pulled up, or the US media highlights things. Did not act on Myanmar story until NYT report. (11/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
No clarity on whether there are India specific community standards, or how chain of command works. It's also likely that global teams would rely on the understanding of local teams. 
FB has a history of move fast and break things. They act only when there's a major problem.(10/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: are still active on FB. FB needs to do better. They have the resources to do so. FB's community standards and their implementation keeps on changing. There is clear lack of consistency here. Role of local teams isn't clear. No clarity on how algos operate. (9/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
We need more evidence here to indicate a political bias. Every company has a bias towards power: every industrialist gives great ratings for the budget. Ankhi Das will recco what is best for Facebook as a business.
4. FB needs to do better: Groups with hate speech (8/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: FB censored memes related to PM Modi, protests against govt policies, and people who shared these. A bias towards power doesn't mean a bias towards a party. Ankhi Das made a recommendation that was biased towards power and reducing business threat from the government. (7/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: FB tends to lean towards power, and there's inaction there. We've seen that in Myanmar (where FB had to apologise), in Philippines, and now allegedly in India. FB serves governments who can block it. Caravan story suggests that (6/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Large platforms have to be held to higher level of scrutiny, expectations of transparency, neutrality because of their power.

3. FB has a bias towards power: As per Pro-Publica in 2017, FB has some categories of users that it treats as protected, including White Men. (5/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 2. FB is powerful: FB has ABILITY to benefit a political party. We have anecdotes, not statistical evidence. We are dependent on the benevolence of platforms to not harm democracy, or enable other govts to do so. (4/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
regarding implementation of community standards, and role of local teams, access to information. This needs to be open to public scrutiny.
d FB has to improve implementation of community stds. Given their scale (+that of YouTube & Twitter), this needs to be expected of them (3/n)

text:
for not taking down hate speech

retweet_text: It’s reductive. Goes nowhere. While I do understand that things are super polarised right now and therefore more either/or, these hyper-partisan approaches are the new normal (for the last half a decade or so), its not useful in taking the debate/discussion forward.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @venkatananth: The convenient or the easy way out would be to reduce anything and everything to a partisan issue (as it is happening wrt…
retweet_text: The convenient or the easy way out would be to reduce anything and everything to a partisan issue (as it is happening wrt Ankhi Das and FB following the WSJ story) or as it happens in the US. But that’s not what this should be about. Understand these companies first.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @venkatananth: But any reading into Facebook (or any other platform) & its role in shaping democracy as we know it today, would be incom…
retweet_text: But any reading into Facebook (or any other platform) & its role in shaping democracy as we know it today, would be incomplete if you don’t pad it with political science. I am increasingly finding myself in the camp which says “to understand tech, read more of political science.”

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @venkatananth: These books are not all *about* Facebook. While some, of course, are about the company, others delve into some of the mor…
retweet_text: These books are not all *about* Facebook. While some, of course, are about the company, others delve into some of the more important questions — its impact on democracy, the Cambridge Analytica scandal, how political operators game platforms like FB and so on.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:

— The Facebook Effect by David Kirkpatrick (from 2010)
— Chaos Monkeys
— The Internet of Garbage by Sarah Jeo…
retweet_text:
(Contd...)

— The Facebook Effect by David Kirkpatrick (from 2010)
— Chaos Monkeys
— The Internet of Garbage by Sarah Jeong
— Lie Machines by Philip N Howard
— Information Wars by Richard Stengel
— Like War by PW Singer and Emerson T Brooking
— The Attention Merchants by Tim Wu

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @AnantRangaswami: @paritoshZero @The_Sorcerer @nixxin Responsible, big brands are waking up to the need to worry about the ambience that…
retweet_text:
@paritoshZero @The_Sorcerer @nixxin Responsible, big brands are waking up to the need to worry about the ambience that ads appear in —not just the cost. We’ll see more of this in India.
The trouble is, support (or lack of support) for a news brand is conflated with support (or lack of it) for a political party.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Reach is only one part of it. It's never "just an ad". 

Brand owners have a responsibility to their brand. Businesses have a responsibility to society. What they support reflects on them.

Channels will respond to brands leaving, more than users switching.

Example: YouTube,2017 https://t.co/VuBpCynV3Z

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
This will be a long haul. Countries that play by common rules = global Internet.

Countries that dont, will find their co's & money rejected. 

India needs to rework its policies (PDP Bill) to restrict govt access, else eventually join the rejects. 

Junk its China envy.
(9/9)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
7. What we need: for a global Internet, is TRUST in cyberspace. 
We need to address issues of jurisdiction & data sharing in case of crimes. 
We need states to enable attribution in cyber attacks. 
We need disarmament of cyber weapons.

 (8/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
6. A thought experiment: Imagine TikTok as an Indian co challenging FB. Imagine India has a Personal Data Protection Law that allows unfettered govt access to data (that’s the plan), and nationalises data, the way it is planning to, with NPD? How would the US react?

(7/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
5. 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗦𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗶𝗴𝗻𝘁𝘆: US-EU data sharing Privacy Shield has been struck down in EU + Microsoft says TikTok data of US citizens = stored in US. This boosts data localisation arguments. Means a splinternet. 

For a global Internet, we need to rebuild trust. (6/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
4. Control: Chinese govt, under law,can exert a lot of control over its co's, but democratic world has laws that restrict this. (Ps: India is going the China way here). If there aren't adequate protections and trust, bans will follow. 

Our openness cannot be our weakness. (5/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 3. Five Eyes: TikTok's US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand ops are being sold. With UK, these 5 are called Five Eyes, which share 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙚𝙡𝙡𝙜𝙚𝙣𝙘𝙚 with each other. TikTok probably anticipates a ban in all these, but want a separate UK negotiation (more revenue). (4/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. Wasn't going to last: Major restrictions for foreign co's to play in China, but Chinese co's have a free run outside. Something was going to give, eventually, and it has. China-Tech is going to have a tough time in most countries. 

Our openness cannot be our weakness. (3/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 1. This is looking like the end of TikTok's global ambitions: banned in India (the worlds largest user market outside of China) and the US (the largest ad revenue market in the world). Caveat: We don't know how Trump/Biden will look at China post elections. (2/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
With Trump signing an Executive Order to ban twitter, we can't ignore the geopolitics of this. This also comes at a time when Microsoft is in talks to buy TikTok's operations in the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand:

(1/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
I've had many many conversations with friends who are VCs over the past two years about why they need to get involved with tech policy, especially with all the shit that's happening in the tech policy space in India. 

This is great vision from @singh_sequoia and @Sequoia_India

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Big news: Sequoia capital has hired @ShwetaRKohli as its head of public policy. This is the 1st VC to hire in that role, & my bet is, it won't be the last.  

Tech Policy is where a lot of crazy action is, and my guess is that other VC's will follow suit.

text:

text:

text:
RT @Banbreach: @nixxin One very, very important aspect that we seem to miss here is the breadth of exposure. 

1. When was the breach ident…
retweet_text:
@nixxin One very, very important aspect that we seem to miss here is the breadth of exposure. 

1. When was the breach identified?
2. When did the breach happen (estimated)?
3. Was it a one time access or, were there multiple accesses?

text: Do read @Aditi_muses 's story here https://t.co/vL7K3OT4Eb

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
This data can be used for phishing attacks over voice, text & email.

2. This is a responsible disclosure from Dunzo, & should be acknowledged. Many many co's do not disclose breaches. 

QUESTION

What else could Dunzo have done? If you think they've done enough here, let me know
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
3. How was Dunzo giving access to a database with emails & phone numbers to a vendor.

IMPORTANTLY 

1. It's not that this data cannot be useful for hackers. Email addresses and phone numbers are data that users do not change. 

+
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. We don't know if email addresses of all users have been compromised, or only some.

2. Who the vendor is. Dunzo hasn't disclosed the name.

There remains a risk (if the vendor wasn't working exclusively with Dunzo) that other databases could have been compromised.

+
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. Attackers compromised servers of a third party that Dunzo works with, and accessed the Dunzo database through them.

2. Payment info (credit cards etc) was not compromised

3. Passwords were not compromised because Dunzo uses OTPs

What we don't know 👇
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Dunzo, one of India's most popular hyper-local delivery apps (funded by Google) said its user phone numbers and email addresses were breached in a #cybersecurity incident.

Here's what we know 👇

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 3. Big question: what does blocking mean? Does it mean that the apps (from the 59) you've downloaded will stop functioning? Or does it mean that apps will be blocked at an ISP level? Or will the app store and play store stop downloads? (5/6)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. The usage of Section 69 to block links and sites is not new. Govt meets platforms to block online content under Section 69. Before the pandemic it was every 10 days, on an average. Now it is every 2 days (4/6)
https://t.co/f1TL3NU8d5
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Thus, this is a POLITICAL decision. It has been announced to send China a message. It should not be seen as anything but a political decision. No change in way these apps function over the past 3 months. If this is the right decision, why wasn't it taken a year ago? (3/6)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 1. This is the very first time, to my knowledge, that the Indian govt has actually ANNOUNCED a ban on apps under Section 69 of the IT Act. You know what's surprising? They don't NEED to announce it. Section 69 allows for secret govt blocking. (2/6)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Well, we survived. I bought Allwin dinner.

Just for good luck, I buy Allwin dinner (at least) once every year now. 

He gets free food. I get great company for dinner. And good luck.

Win-win. Lol.

(3/3)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
We were on the verge of shutting down. 

My jokingly morbid bet in, I think, June 2017: if MediaNama survives, I'll buy Allwin dinner. If it doesn't, he'll buy me dinner. That way, I get at least something out of it. Kinda win-win for me in a funny kind of way. (2/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: I would urge @internetfreedom to take this up. Section 69 needs transparency and accountability. Government blocking orders need to be limited and ideally not secret.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
+ & zero accountability. I wouldn't be surprised if the order to block @Aakar__Patel 's account in India is via a section 69 order. It could have been sent by @GoI_MeitY , which is under @rsprasad .

This is why Section 69 needs to be challenged. +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: + Section 69 was left untouched by the SC, because it was felt that there were enough protections built in. This section allows the government of India to block sites and links SECRETLY. A bureaucrat has to sign off. And there is a review. There is ZERO transparency +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: +Bunched along with that were many other cases. 2 other clauses in the IT Act were challenged. Section 79a &Section 69a. Section79 was weak bec people could get content blocked online by just sending an email. That led to censorship. It was strengthened by the SC,but not much +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
His strategy:
1. Filing a case brings local visibility for the issue, and brings it into "limelight" locally.
2. Psychological & financial pressure: It costs an activist nothing to file a case, Twitter Rs. 5-10 Lakh per case. 10-12 cases = 1-2 CR https://t.co/5zrXH3iFga (6/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(16/n) India is already amending its IT rules to enforce, mainly:
1. Traceability of originators of a message or update.
2. Proactive takedown of content

So this might lead to @rsprasad saying his Ministry is justified in making these amendments
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (15/n) The actual problem is what it signals for platform regulation worldwide. The White House is signaling that it's okay to add further regulations on platforms re how they deal with content. This is especially bad for India. +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (14/n) But that's not going to fly. FCC Commissioner @JRosenworcel (Who is also supportive of net neutrality. Yay!) has already pushed back. https://t.co/D4GUcWCcck https://t.co/fGO7f2JHC7
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(13/n) 
(B)  taken after failing to provide adequate notice, reasoned explanation, or a meaningful opportunity to be heard.

These are tricky, especially the notice bit. All platforms have automated takedowns and peoples tweets get censored regularly.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(12/n) And the conditions under which an action restricting access to or availability of material is not “taken in good faith”, especially if they are 
(A)  deceptive, pretextual, or inconsistent with a provider’s terms of service; or
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(11/n) help him because it's pretty broad provision and the only part that can be challenged is the "good faith" bit. Which will go to court. Which the White House can easily lose. 
2. The FCC has been asked to propose regulations to clarify how the two parts (A and B) interact.+
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(10/n) Now Trump has asked for the following action to be taken. 
1. "All executive departments and agencies should ensure that their application of section 230(c) properly reflects the narrow purpose of the section and take all appropriate actions in this regard." 

This won't +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (9/n)3. When a platform "removes or restricts access to content and its actions do not meet the criteria of subparagraph (c)(2)(A), it is engaged in editorial conduct", and should be exposed to liability like any traditional editor and publisher. https://t.co/s1xflT6mKV
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (8/n) 2. Platform power&neutrality:handful of companies controlling "vital avenues for our national discourse under the guise of promoting open forums for debate", while having"blanket immunity when they use their power to censor content and silence viewpoints that they dislike."
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (6/n) Trump has cites 16,000 complaints of online platforms censoring or otherwise taking action against users based on their political viewpoints an anti-right winged bias wrt Twitter in his executive order. This will resonate in India👇
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
(5/n) A lot rides on that phrase "good faith". Trump's executive order has the following policy goals: 
1. Act against platforms not acting in “good faith”; which are engaging in "deceptive or pretextual actions" to "stifle viewpoints with which they disagree."
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (4/n) 230(c) allows these platforms to impose their own community standards and "in good faith", violate free speech rights of US Citizens by restricting access to content which might not abide by these standards: https://t.co/0q8fw35S9N
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (3/n) This is why Facebook allows you to post on Facebook. Blogs and Reddit allow you to comment. YouTube allows you to upload your videos. ISPs allow you to create your own site. Therefore, 230(c) (& India's IT Act Section 79) PROTECT the platforms that ENABLE our free speech.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: (2/n) Reason why we're can upload content on sites like YouTube,FB,Reddit,Twitter,every forum,all blogs (w comments) is because 230(c) of US Communications Decency Act provides safe harbor: platform/ISP is not liable for content that you and I create( but we are). +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:

text: RT @gautambhatia88: Also, remember this: what X or Y says on social media is not even remotely relevant if the judgments of the Court are f…
retweet_text:
Also, remember this: what X or Y says on social media is not even remotely relevant if the judgments of the Court are fundamentally indefensible, on the touchstone of legal reasoning. That is where the focus should be, at the present moment. 

(9/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @gautambhatia88: So let's understand how power relations actually work, who holds and wields power, and who can actually exercise "influ…
retweet_text:
So let's understand how power relations actually work, who holds and wields power, and who can actually exercise "influence." 

(8/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @gautambhatia88: What is more likely to "influence" the Court? When figures who wield this much power accuse the Court of having set bac…
retweet_text:
What is more likely to "influence" the Court? When figures who wield this much power accuse the Court of having set back the Indian economy because of its 2G/Spectrum judgments (without any evidence) [this happened], or some dude with a Twitter account venting?

(7/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @gautambhatia88: And what do you say when individuals exercising such power and influence over the Court themselves pen op-eds darkly hi…
retweet_text:
And what do you say when individuals exercising such power and influence over the Court themselves pen op-eds darkly hinting at "lobbies", echoing the worst kind of prejudice-stirring that we normally see government law officers engaging in these days? 

(6/n)

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @gautambhatia88: + you stand up, and get made an amicus - with the power to influence how the Court will interpret the fundamental right…
retweet_text:
+ you stand up, and get made an amicus - with the power to influence how the Court will interpret the fundamental rights of 1.3 billion people.

That is power.
That is influence.
That is unaccountable power and influence.

Not "social media diatribes."

(5/n)

text: Late payments can be a means of creating dependency and vulnerability, because rule of law is weak in the country, and the entertainment industry is, in parts, a cartel.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: That impacts cashflows turnaround, and ability to invest, and economic growth. All stemming from fact that you can't trust that you'll be paid. India is a rough market to operate in, for an individual, for a business. Really sad to see how the TV biz operates. +
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Sometimes some agencies want additional payments, bribes, a haircut, to release payments. Which is why, because we pay everyone (incl vendors) on time, we have to keep months of working capital. Extrapolate that to an entire industry, and idle cash. To an entire country.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Among the worst aspects of business and work in India are the norms related to payments cycle, that give rise to indebtedness. Via this, found out that TV actors get paid after 90 days. In advertising, it can be 120+ days. Once, agency paid us in December for an ad run in April. https://t.co/4Z9gmvd6S2

text: Adding a correction here: as per Reuters, CCI is considering investigation. It hasn't been approved. Hasn't begun yet. It is reviewing the complaint filed by the lawyer.
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Needless to say, if the CCI takes this up, it will be precedence setting, and really interesting to read, because this will probably be the first time that data issues are considered, if they are.

 (11/11)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
1. Does control over data in messaging make WhatsApp dominant in payments?
2. Does being dominant in payments/messaging mean there is abuse of that dominance?
3. Does the agreement between WhatsApp & WhatsApp payments (if separate companies?) mean there's an MFN agreement? (10/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
And control over data should be considered for determining the dominant position of any enterprise, and that any “most favoured nation” (MFN) kind of agreements can have anti-competitive effects, seeking to facilitate a cartel, and should be scrutinised.

Some questions (9/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
The committee said that the 

“the ability to amass and process huge volume of data and use it to develop new and innovative services is a parameter critical to the discussion on the role of competition in new age markets.” 
(8/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: Correction: CCI is considering investigating WhatsApp. An investigation hasn't begun. The considerations I've mentioned still remain 👇 https://t.co/ZNi2sRB9Qs
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
Will be sharing of data between WhatsApp and WhatsApp pay. Data sharing between services hasn't been explored by CCI, but data related came up in a competition law review committee 
https://t.co/iJmkxmrUVX
(7/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
It will have to prove that that is abuse of dominance. For that it will have to wait for an impact of that dominance+ for WhatsApp to become dominant in that space. It's too early for that decision imo. 
7. Only grounds that could come up, and this will be for the 1st time (6/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
5. WhatsApp is doing UPI. It's a highly competitive space. There is no likelihood of abuse of dominance by any player. Situation in payments is changing rapidly each month. 
6. If the CCI will stop a dominant player in one space from entering a crowded, competitive space, (5/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
It could be just payments, which includes cash, which is HUGE. Where is WhatsApp dominant? None of these spaces.
4. Who is dominant? In case of digital payments, SBI for cards, and either of Google Pay, Phonepe, maybe Paytm for UPI. UPI, pre COVID19 was ~1.2 bn txns / month (4/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: 3. Now payments is highly crowded, and dominance in payments depends on definition of "market". It cld be digital payments, which is huge (PLUG: buy our report, 100+ charts on digital payments here https://t.co/BqeveRpKBj ). Or it could be UPI, which is smaller. Or (3/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
2. CCI has investigated WhatsApp for dominance and abuse of dominance in messaging in 2017, where there is barely anyone else. https://t.co/oLkjtxvjXs
It concluded that WhatsApp is dominant, but there is no abuse of dominance. (2/n)
retweet_text: None

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
THREAD regarding CCI investigating WhatsApp for abuse of dominance for entering payments:

1. Here's the reuters story: https://t.co/uZMpX9GXGu

2. CCI looks at two aspects: market dominance AND it's abuse. Both conditions need to be satisfied. 
(1/n)
retweet_text: None

They have applied for one, and have  for now already partnered with Indian financial companies to offer services https://t.co/HMx7gV9AOf

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @raj_s: It’s incredible that the government has this fantastic infra for collecting money from citizens - IT, GST, TDS, PM Cares etc etc…
retweet_text: It’s incredible that the government has this fantastic infra for collecting money from citizens - IT, GST, TDS, PM Cares etc etc... But when they have to return some of that money, it’s lost in a labyrinth of offsets, meaningless discounts, deferred taxes, conditional loans... 😒

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: I have written extensively about this in the past. Economic activity in India has been slowing down before covid-19 stuck a…
retweet_text: I have written extensively about this in the past. Economic activity in India has been slowing down before covid-19 stuck and that will create more problems for us in the months to come.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: The trouble of course is largely on the demand side. In today's environment with one in four working Indians unemployed, I…
retweet_text: The trouble of course is largely on the demand side. In today's environment with one in four working Indians unemployed, I am not really sure how much the govt can do about this in the short-term.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Finally, as I said in the beginning, through today's package announcements the government is trying to get other institutio…
retweet_text: Finally, as I said in the beginning, through today's package announcements the government is trying to get other institutions to spend money, through various incentives and guarantees.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Basically, individual's money will be returned to him or her, in the hope that he or she will spend it now than wait for it…
retweet_text: Basically, individual's money will be returned to him or her, in the hope that he or she will spend it now than wait for it to accumulate in the future. Wonder, how that can be added to the govt's economic package.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @kaul_vivek: Ah forgot this one.
PF contribution of both employer and employee will be reduced to 10% each from existing 12% each for al…
retweet_text:
Ah forgot this one.
PF contribution of both employer and employee will be reduced to 10% each from existing 12% each for all establishments covered by EPFO for next 3 months. This adds Rs 6,750 crore to liquidity apparently.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @kaul_vivek: It just fulfils the govt's need to show that they are doing something big. 
It also fulfils's the need of the citizens to u…
retweet_text:
It just fulfils the govt's need to show that they are doing something big. 
It also fulfils's the need of the citizens to understand whether something is happening or not. To that extent it works.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: You will see the media add up all these big numbers and say a package of so many lakh crore has been offered. The number cu…
retweet_text: You will see the media add up all these big numbers and say a package of so many lakh crore has been offered. The number currently going around on WhatsApp forwards is Rs 6 lakh crore. I haven't bothered to add and check because I think the number doesn't mean anything.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: All in all, as I have been saying for a while, the government's finances have been in a mess for a while now. Today's packa…
retweet_text: All in all, as I have been saying for a while, the government's finances have been in a mess for a while now. Today's package and the way it has been structured reflects that. The govt's financial commitment to the package is minimal and that is understandable.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @kaul_vivek: All pending refunds to charitable trusts and non-corporate businesses & professions shall be issued immediately.
Will be su…
retweet_text:
All pending refunds to charitable trusts and non-corporate businesses & professions shall be issued immediately.
Will be surprised if this is also included as a part of the package. It's money owed to people being returned.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Again, how do you add this to the overall thing? I mean, others may still not be ready to lend to these companies despite t…
retweet_text: Again, how do you add this to the overall thing? I mean, others may still not be ready to lend to these companies despite the government guarantee, given that the guarantee is up to 20%. Govt's commitment is up to the extent of max Rs 9,000 crore (20% of Rs 45,000 crore).

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: The govt is guaranteeing the borrowing of NBFCs, HFCs and MFIs with low credit rating, up to the extent of 20%. This will r…
retweet_text: The govt is guaranteeing the borrowing of NBFCs, HFCs and MFIs with low credit rating, up to the extent of 20%. This will result in a liquidity of Rs 45,000 crore. This basically means that these firms will be able to borrow up to Rs 45,000 crore, if others are willing to lend.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: At best, the overall default rate of corporates can be used. As of Sep 30, it was around 17%. So, 17% of Rs 3 lakh crore wo…
retweet_text: At best, the overall default rate of corporates can be used. As of Sep 30, it was around 17%. So, 17% of Rs 3 lakh crore works out to around Rs 50,000 crore. Given that these loans are only for companies with a turnover of less than Rs 100 crore, the rate of default will be lower

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:
RT @kaul_vivek: Credit guarantee is a good move. But banks should not be forced to give out loans. 
Again, adding the entire Rs 3 lakh cror…
retweet_text:
Credit guarantee is a good move. But banks should not be forced to give out loans. 
Again, adding the entire Rs 3 lakh crore to the package makes no sense. The govt is not giving out this money.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Now, the biggest announcement today, the Rs 3 lakh crore, Collateral-free Automatic Loans for Businesses, including MSMEs t…
retweet_text: Now, the biggest announcement today, the Rs 3 lakh crore, Collateral-free Automatic Loans for Businesses, including MSMEs to be provided by banks/NBFCs (not the government). The govt has provided a 100% credit guarantee. Its outflow will be limited to the extent of defaults.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: But ultimately it's a loan, which needs to be repaid. And should be seen like that. This is not to say that this is not a g…
retweet_text: But ultimately it's a loan, which needs to be repaid. And should be seen like that. This is not to say that this is not a good move. But the marketing bit really sucks.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Or take the case of Rs 90,000 crore being provided to DISCOMs as a loan against receivables. It's a loan. It provides liqui…
retweet_text: Or take the case of Rs 90,000 crore being provided to DISCOMs as a loan against receivables. It's a loan. It provides liquidity. Helps, given the fact that power distribution companies owe a lot of money to power generation companies, which in turn owe a lot of money to banks.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Take the reductions in TDS/TCS. It helps institutions that they don't have to pay a portion of the tax immediately. But the…
retweet_text: Take the reductions in TDS/TCS. It helps institutions that they don't have to pay a portion of the tax immediately. But they do need to pay it later.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: Of course, then they are torturing these numbers to ensure that everything adds up to Rs 20 lakh crore. I had done a thread…
retweet_text:
Of course, then they are torturing these numbers to ensure that everything adds up to Rs 20 lakh crore. I had done a thread on the RBI in the morning, to explain this. 
More such examples in today's FinMin PC as well.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @kaul_vivek: My takeaway from today's FinMin PC is this: The government is trying to get other institutions to spend money, through vari…
retweet_text:
My takeaway from today's FinMin PC is this: The government is trying to get other institutions to spend money, through various incentives and guarantees. 
I guess that's pretty much what they can do given their financial state.

Not sure of what happened to Jio. They used to be more reliable prior to the lockdown.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text:

My wireline Excitel connection is down regularly, &now I'm even streaming Netflix on TV using the Airtel hotspot

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @prajwalmanipal: Officials then decided to hold the funeral rites at the Hindu Rudrabhoomi in Baddakatte in Bantwal town but the cremati…

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @prajwalmanipal: Similarly, the cremation was not allowed to be held at Nandigudde after opposition from local residents and Vedavyas Ka…
retweet_text: Similarly, the cremation was not allowed to be held at Nandigudde after opposition from local residents and Vedavyas Kamath, MLA of Mangaluru South.

name: Nikhil Pahwa
text: RT @prajwalmanipal: First, the plan was to hold the cremation in Pachanady but locals gathered there in the night and eventually Mangaluru…
retweet_text: First, the plan was to hold the cremation in Pachanady but locals gathered there in the night and eventually Mangaluru North MLA Dr. Bharat Shetty pacified the crowd saying the cremation will not be held there at any cost. (The MLA is a medical doctor).
